fields.summary: [Java] Add documentation to all classes and enable checkstyle for class javadocs

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
emkornfield commented on pull request #4243: ARROW-5250: [Java] Add javadoc comments to public methods, remove style check suppression.
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4243
 
 
   Apologies for the large CL.  After this the one last large javadoc fixing of 2019 is to enable checkstyle to types as well and add missing docs to those.
   
   If possible my review preference would be as suggested edits if at all possible but any feedback is welcome.
   
   In addition to javadocs, I also added private constructors to classes containing only static utility methods.
   
   For a small set of test methods I converted them to "private" instead of providing javadocs.
   
   The approach taken was to provide minimal useful javadoc and not necessarily completely formatted with all parameters, etc.  The intent is to enable style checking to "stop" the bleeding so patch authors can provide useful documentation for new API methods going forward.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

jacques-n commented on issue #4243: ARROW-5250: [Java] Add javadoc comments to public methods, remove style check suppression.
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4243#issuecomment-488988942
 
 
   Nice job Micah. Super appreciated! A few high level comments at this point:
   
   I'm against requirement for javadocs on public methods/classes in tests (I am assuming we have that req based on the changes). Sure, if there is something helpful to comment we should do it but I find many of the comments on tests to be just duplicating the name of the test method for example. In fact, in some cases here the test names have more meaning than the comments.
   
   It also looks like we require a javadoc on methods but don't require a javadoc that includes arguments for that method. It seems like we should require both or neither.
   
   For the public -> private methods, can you submit those changes as a separate patch? They should get more scrutiny and I'm likely to miss some in a patch with this many changes (partly because I find reviews much harder to do in GH than Gerrit... sorry.) Assuming that some of those methods are not test methods, I would also make sure the Dremio team aren't actively relying on those apis.
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

emkornfield commented on issue #4243: ARROW-5250: [Java] Add javadoc comments to public methods, remove style check suppression.
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4243#issuecomment-489291722
 
 
   @jacques-n thanks for the comments.  I pushed an updated version, that 
   1.  Splits the changes into 2 commits the first is all the code change (it seems given the small size and trivial nature a separate PR might be overkill but if you still want one I can do it) the second is all the javadoc changes.
   2.  Changed the configuration to exclude test directories and reverted all comments in the test directory (I'll admit to some laziness on not putting much effort into test javadocs).
   3.  Removed the requirement for main methods to have javadocs (but left the current ones in place).
   
   In regards to:
   > It also looks like we require a javadoc on methods but don't require a javadoc that includes arguments for that method. It seems like we should require both or neither.
   
   I disagree:
   1.   I think some docs as long as not useless or incorrect are better then documentation that doesn't have parameters.
   2.  In many cases documenting params is redundant (doesn't add value).  I'm not claiming that there are some methods that I added that couldn't benefit from parameter documentation, but I tried to be judicious and would prefer to address this on a case-by-case basis.  The [Google Style Guide](https://google.github.io/styleguide/javaguide.html#s7-javadoc) that we use implicitly allows for leaving out parameter documentation and explicit \@return documentation to avoid this redundancy.
   
   If you are amenable, I'd like to resolve the requirement for parameter documentation by:
   1.  Getting consensus on the mailing list as to the communities preference for all method javadoc that checkstyle allows.
   2.  Following up with a separate PR.  The size of this PR is already large, I apologize for that, and as I stated above, I think it adds value as a stand-alone basis.  Adding the requirement for parameters will only make it larger. 
   
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org
